questions.question: A patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumor, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.explanation: hemangioblastoma. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not characterized by the presence of both renal tumor and cerebellar mass.

questions.question: Most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy?
questions.explanation: disease, is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in the body, primarily affecting the liver and brain. It is the most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy. Incorrect options: Option B: Diffuse glomerulosclerosis: Diffuse glomerulosclerosis refers to the widespread scarring and thickening of the glomeruli in the kidneys due to long-standing uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. This condition is a major cause of end-stage renal disease. Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a distinct kidney disease characterized by scarring in specific areas of the glomeruli. While it can be associated with some forms of kidney damage, it is not the most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy. Option D. Armani Ebstein change: Armani Ebstein change is not a recognized term or characteristic finding related to diabetic nephropathy Reference: .

questions.question: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Membranous nephropathy Explanation: Characteristic Features of Membranous Nephropathy Feature Description Primary Cause Autoantibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes (most common in idiopathic cases). Secondary Causes Autoimmune diseases (SLE), infections (Hepatitis B/C), drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine), and malignancies (lung, breast, colon cancer). Nephrotic Syndrome Features Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia, lipiduria. Risk of Thrombosis Renal vein thrombosis is a known complication. Light Microscopy Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) without hypercellularity. Electron Microscopy (EM) Subepithelial immune deposits create a "spike and dome" appearance . Immunofluorescence Granular IgG and C3 deposits along the GBM. PLA2R Antibodies Specific for primary membranous nephropathy and helps differentiate from secondary causes. Treatment ACE inhibitors/ARBs (reduce proteinuria), steroids + immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide, rituximab) for severe cases. Prognosis I spontaneous remission, I persistent proteinuria, I progress to ESRD. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option B) (FSGS) is characterised by scarring and sclerosis of the glomeruli. While FSGS can occur in the setting of cancer, it is not commonly associated with solid cancer of the bowel. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C) (MPGN) is characterised by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and the proliferation of cells within the glomeruli.MPGN is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel. Dense deposit disease (Option D) , also known as C3 glomerulopathy, is characterised by the abnormal accumulation of complement component C3 within the glomeruli.Dense deposit disease is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

questions.question: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Minimal change disease Explanation: Effacement of podocyte foot processes refers to the flattening or loss of the foot processes of podocytes, specialized cells located in the kidney's glomerulus. This structural change is a hallmark of minimal change disease (also called minimal change nephrotic syndrome) . It presents with severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and lipiduria. While the glomeruli appear normal under light microscopy, the characteristic finding of podocyte foot process effacement can only be observed under electron microscopy. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (2-6 years) and responds well to corticosteroid therapy. Steroid-resistant glomerulonephritis (Option A) does not typically show effacement of podocyte foot processes. Instead, it may show more severe glomerular damage. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) (Option C) is marked by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is not typically associated with podocyte effacement. Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option D) is associated with sclerosis and fibrosis in the glomeruli, and effacement of podocyte foot processes is not a characteristic finding.

questions.question: A 51-year-old male patient presents with complaints of hematuria. On examination, he is normotensive and has pedal edema. Investigations reveal that the patient has no glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. His renal biopsy finding is given below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Anti-GBM antibodies Explanation: The presence of crescents on the renal biopsy & clinical presentation suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) . This condition can be caused by an anti-glomerular basement membrane (Anti-GBM) . Anti-GBM antibodies are used to confirm the diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome , a form of RPGN. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM Ab-mediated) Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated) Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type) Includes: Idiopathic Goodpasture syndrome Includes: Idiopathic Postinfectious glomerulonephritis Lupus (SLE) nephritis Henoch-Schönlein purpura IgA nephropathy Includes: ANCA-associated Idiopathic Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis ) Microscopic polyangiitis IF finding: Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3) IF finding: Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits) IF finding: No deposits Electron microscopy: R PGN causes R upture and w R inkling of GBM Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) (Option A) are typically associated with systemic autoimmune diseases such as SLE. While SLE can cause glomerulonephritis and affect the kidneys, the presence of crescents on the renal biopsy suggests a more acute and rapidly progressive disease, making SLE a less likely diagnosis in this case. HIV RNA (Option C): HIV infection can cause renal complications, including

questions.question: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in which of the following conditions? HIV SLE CLL Hepatitis B
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3, 4 Explanation: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis can be associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), and hepatitis B virus (HBV). Causes of MPGN: Primary MPGN: Idiopathic Secondary Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) (typically type I) is more common in adults and occurs in the following conditions: Chronic immune complex disorders, including SLE, hepatitis B and C infections (especially with cryoglobulinemia), endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses, HIV infection , and schistosomiasis. α 1-Antitrypsin deficiency. Malignant diseases, particularly lymphoid tumours, like chronic lymphocytic leukaemia . Pathology Light Microscope Electron Microscope Immunofluorescence Type I MPGN Mesangial proliferative or membranoproliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening and Splitting. (Double-contour or tram track appearance). Subendothelial and mesangial deposits. IgG ++ C3 (C1q ++ C4 may also present) Type II MPGN (Dense Deposit Disease) Dense intramembranous deposits. C3; no C1q or C4 Membranous Nephropathy Diffuse capillary wall thickening. Subepithelial deposits. Granular IgG and C3; diffuse Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) Focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis. Effacement of foot processes; epithelial denudation. Focal; IgM + C3 in many cases

questions.question: What type of urinary casts would you expect in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Maltese cross cast Explanation: Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency , leading to globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) accumulation in tissues, including the kidneys. A characteristic finding in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also referred to as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts. These casts form when Gb3 precipitates within the renal tubules and appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when observed under polarized light. Renal Cast Type Condition Associated Images Hyaline casts Normal conditions, Fever, Pregnancy Muddy Brown casts Acute tubular necrosis Waxy casts Chronic renal failure Fatty casts Nephrotic syndrome RBC casts Glomerulonephritis WBC casts Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis Epithelial casts Renal epithelial injury Broad casts Chronic renal disease

questions.question: What is the most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Kimmelstiel Wilson Nodules Explanation: Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules (aka Nodular glomerulosclerosis ) are a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy. They are ovoid or spherical , PAS-positive nodules found in the mesangial core of glomeruli. They are often accompanied by mesangiolysis and sometimes surrounded by dilated capillary loops. Armanni Ebstein change (Option B) refers to glycogen accumulation in renal tubular epithelial cells, seen in severe or poorly controlled diabetes, but it is not specific to diabetic nephropathy. Aschoff nodule (Option C) is a histological hallmark of rheumatic fever, typically found in the myocardium. Anitschkow cell (Option D) is a macrophage with a characteristic caterpillar-like nucleus, seen in rheumatic fever, not diabetic nephropathy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? Most common primary renal malignancy Associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3 Not associated with paraneoplastic syndrome The classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is seen.
questions.explanation: erythrocytosis, and hypertension. Clear cell carcinoma: Prevalence : Accounts for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. (Most common) Tumour Characteristics : Composed of cells with clear or granular cytoplasm and a nonpapillary pattern. Familial vs. Sporadic : Primarily sporadic (95%), but can also be familial. Genetic Alterations : Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3 in 98% of cases. The VHL gene, located in this region, is a key tumour suppressor gene. Classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is commonly observed in kidney tumours, although it may not be present in all cases. Morphology: Origin : Arises from proximal tubular epithelium. Gross Appearance : Bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses. Yellow colour due to lipid accumulation in tumour cells. It may have areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and cystic regions. Histopathology: Most tumours are well-differentiated & some may show nuclear atypia, bizarre nuclei, and giant cells. The growth pattern varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular (resembling tubules). The tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm containing glycogen and lipids. The tumours have delicate branching vasculature and may show cystic and solid areas. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 952 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8946620/

questions.question: Tamm-Horsfall protein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Renal casts Explanation: Tamm-Horsfall protein, produced in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle, is the most abundant protein in normal urine and serves as a marker of tubular function. It plays a key role in preventing urinary tract infections and is the primary component of hyaline casts, the most common type of urinary casts. Incorrect Options: Mural thrombi (Option A) are blood clots that stick to the walls of blood vessels or the heart. They are not related to the Tamm-Horsfall protein , which is specific to renal tubular function and not involved in thrombus formation. Curschmann spirals (Option B) are mucus plugs found in the sputum of patients with asthma or other obstructive pulmonary diseases. Bence-Jones proteins (Option D) are free immunoglobulin light chains found in urine and are linked to multiple myeloma. Unlike the Tamm-Horsfall protein, which is a normal renal protein involved in renal casts, Bence-Jones proteins are abnormal products resulting from plasma cell malignancies. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2304. 686

questions.question: A 48-year-old man presents with facial puffiness, frothy urine, hypertension, a history of hepatitis B infection, and microscopic hematuria. A kidney biopsy reveals a spike and dome pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Membranous Nephropathy Explanation: The combination of frothy urine, hypertension, and the biopsy finding points to the diagnosis of Membranous nephropathy, which is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is often associated with hepatitis B and is characterised by the spike and dome pattern on kidney biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposition (primarily IgG and C3) . Membranous Nephropathy: M/C cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients. It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy (colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs (gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions (SLE). In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition , resembling Heymann nephritis lesions. Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase ( CD10 ) . The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease. Pathology Light Microscope Electron Microscope Immunofluorescence Membranous Nephropathy Diffuse capillary wall thickening Subepithelial deposits Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

questions.question: A pediatric patient presents with cola-coloured urine, high blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory tests reveal a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which rises to 4.5 mg/dL after 3 weeks despite treatment. What electron microscopic finding is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Subepithelial deposits Explanation: The clinical presentation, including cola-coloured urine , hypertension , edema , and rising creatinine levels, is highly suggestive of acute glomerulonephritis , particularly post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Subepithelial deposits are characteristic of PSGN in electron microscopy. Pathological findings in PSGN Grossly Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance) . Light microscopy Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells . Electron microscope ‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition. Incorrect Options: Given the worsening renal function (rising creatinine levels) over time and the risk of progression to Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN), a finding of crescent formation (Option C) in the glomeruli would be expected, but it is a histopathological finding & not an electron microscope finding. Subendothelial deposits (Option A) are typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) , not in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) . Mesangial deposits (Option D) are often seen in conditions like IgA nephropathy , membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) , or diabetic nephropathy , but not typically in PSGN .

questions.question: Which of the following will increase in size on electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Alpha 2 globulin Explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by proteinuria , hypoalbuminemia , edema , and hyperlipidemia, and the electrophoresis shows decreased albumin levels and increased levels of alpha-2 globulin. The increase in alpha-2 globulin is due to an increase in macroglobulin, which is a larger protein , and its increase in the bloodstream serves as a compensatory mechanism in nephrotic syndrome to counteract the loss of albumin . Gamma globulin (Option A) does not increase significantly . An increase in gamma globulins is seen in conditions like multiple myeloma or chronic inflammatory conditions , not in nephrotic syndrome. Beta globulin (Option C) increases, but this increase is typically modest compared to the marked rise in alpha-2 globulins . Albumin (Option D) is the major protein that decreases in size on electrophoresis in nephrotic syndrome due to its significant loss in the urine, leading to hypoalbuminemia . Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 636 NIH Link

questions.question: A 47-year-old male with 400 ml urine output per 24 hrs. On histology, he had RPGN with Pauci immune glomerulonephritis with crescents. What is the main etiology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) ANCA Explanation: The clinical presentation of RPGN with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and crescents on histology strongly suggests an ANCA-associated vasculitis . Pauci-immune means that there are few immune complexes present in the glomeruli, which is typical of ANCA-associated vasculitis. ANCA are commonly associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s) , microscopic polyangiitis , and Churg-Strauss syndrome , which can lead to pauci-immune RPGN . Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM antibody-mediated) Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated) Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type) Includes: Idiopathic Goodpasture syndrome- the presence of Anti GBM. (Option A ruled out) Includes: Idiopathic Postinfectious glomerulonephritis Lupus (SLE) nephritis - ANA positive (Option D ruled out) Henoch-Schönlein purpura IgA nephropathy Includes: ANCA-associated Idiopathic Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis ) Microscopic polyangiitis IF finding: Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3) IF finding: Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits) IF finding: No deposits Electron microscopy: R PGN causes R upture and w R inkling of GBM Anti PLA2R (Option C) antibody is primarily associated with membranous nephropathy, which presents with nephrotic syndrome, not RPGN. The histological findings do not align with membranous nephropathy , which typically shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without hypercellularity on light microscopy and a "spike and dome" appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy. glomerulonephritis in an infant. Saudi journal of kidney diseases and transplantation : an official publication of the Saudi Center for Organ Transplantation, Saudi Arabia. 24. 546-8. 10.4103/1319-2442.111061. questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 9-year-old boy who presents with hematuria, hypertension, facial puffiness for 3 days, and a recent history of throat infection two weeks ago, with urine examination showing albumin positivity?
questions.explanation: streptococci, particularly Streptococcus pyogenes, are known to cause post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which can manifest with symptoms like hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness following a throat infection. It's a classic scenario for post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN). Incorrect Options: Option A - Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci: While Group B streptococci are associated with various infections, including neonatal sepsis and meningitis, they are not typically linked to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is a more common presentation in the scenario described. Option B - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium responsible for various infections, such as skin and soft tissue infections, but it is not a common cause of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Option D - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a bacterium commonly associated with medical device-related infections and biofilm formation. It is not typically linked to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.question: A patient presents with hematuria and flank pain. A renal mass is shown in the image provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: histological appearance, which shows plant cells, perinuclear halos, and raisinoid nuclei. It also shows positivity with Hale's colloidal iron stain and has a better prognosis compared to other RCC types. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D do not show plant cells. Reference: .

questions.question: A female presents to the OPD with complaints of dysuria. Based on the microscopic examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Multinucleated Moulding of nuclei Margination of the nucleus Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not consistent with the microscopic examination findings. Reference: .

questions.question: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. This leads to the accumulation of a lipid called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) within various cells and tissues, including the kidneys. One of the characteristic findings in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also known as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts. These casts are formed by the precipitation of Gb3 within the renal tubules. They appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when viewed under polarized light. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of these is nephritic syndrome?
questions.explanation: glomerular inflammation and is associated with the following clinical features: Hematuria Proteinuria Hypertension Edema Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are nephrotic syndromes. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 45-year-old mal e patient who presented with scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings . What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: histopathological appearance of a seminoma Seminoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor. It typically presents as a painless testicular mass or swelling. Histologically, seminomas consist of uniform, undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nuclei . Incorrect Options: Option B - Yolk-sac tumor: Yolk-sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It primarily occurs in infants and young children. Histologically, yolk-sac tumors exhibit characteristic structures resembling primitive yolk sacs, such as Schiller-Duval bodies. The provided histopathology image does not show the features of a yolk-sac tumor. Option C - Embryonal cell carcinoma: Embryonal cell carcinoma is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It is composed of primitive, undifferentiated germ cells. Histologically, embryonal cell carcinomas often exhibit a mixture of different tissue types and can show features of glandular or tubular structures. The histopathology image provided does not demonstrate the characteristics of an embryonal cell carcinoma. Option D - Teratoma: Teratoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor that contains a variety of tissues derived from three embryonic

questions.question: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.explanation: feature of bladder carcinoma. Hematuria refers to the presence of blood in the urine, and when it occurs without pain, it is often associated with bladder carcinoma. Painless hematuria may occur intermittently or be persistent, and it is an important warning sign that should prompt further evaluation for bladder cancer. Incorrect Options: Option B - Painful hematuria: While hematuria can sometimes be associated with pain, especially in conditions such as urinary tract infections or kidney stones, painful hematuria is less commonly seen in bladder carcinoma. Bladder carcinoma typically presents with painless hematuria as the primary symptom. Option C - Dysuria: Dysuria refers to painful or difficult urination and is not a consistent feature of bladder carcinoma. Dysuria is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections. Option D - Suprapubic mass: The presence of a suprapubic mass is not a specific or consistent feature of bladder carcinoma. Bladder carcinoma may lead to the development of a bladder tumor or a thickened bladder wall, but the presence of a palpable mass is less common. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below, is?
questions.explanation: nephropathy shown in the histopathological image is Kimmelstiel Wilson nodules. These are pathognomonic lesions seen in the kidneys of patients with diabetic nephropathy. They are characterized by the presence of nodular mesangial expansion, thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and hyaline deposits. These changes are indicative of advanced diabetic nephropathy and are associated with the development of proteinuria and progressive renal dysfunction. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.explanation: the abnormal leakage of proteins, particularly albumin, into the urine. This results in hypoalbuminemia. On serum electrophoresis, nephrotic syndrome can present with a characteristic pattern of decreased albumin levels and a prominent alpha-2 band. The decreased albumin leads to a decrease in the albumin peak, and the alpha-2 band becomes more prominent relative to the albumin peak. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria . Looking at the immunofluorescence image below , what is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: of SLE. The immunofluorescence findings in lupus nephritis demonstrate a variety of patterns, including the presence of a "full house" pattern. This pattern shows granular deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q throughout the glomeruli. The "full house" pattern indicates the deposition of immune complexes containing multiple types of antibodies and complement components. Incorrect Options: Option A - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): In FSGS, the immunofluorescence may not reveal any specific immune deposits or show only mild or nonspecific deposits. Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): In PSGN, the immunofluorescence findings show granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the glomerular basement membrane. These immune deposits represent the immune complex deposition caused by the immune response to the streptococcal infection. Option C - Good pasture syndrome: The immunofluorescence findings in Good pasture syndrome reveal linear deposits of IgG along the GBM. These linear deposits correspond to the binding of anti-GBM antibodies to the GBM. Reference: Prepladder Notes
